review.title: RoxyBot-06: Stochastic Prediction and Optimization in TAC Travel
review.abstract: In this paper, we describe our autonomous bidding agent, RoxyBot, who emerged victorious in the travel division of the 2006 Trading Agent Competition in a photo finish. At a high level, the design of many successful trading agents can be summarized as follows: (i) price prediction: build a model of market prices; and (ii) optimization: solve for an approximately optimal set of bids, given this model. To predict, RoxyBot builds a stochastic model of market prices by simulating simultaneous ascending auctions. To optimize, RoxyBot relies on the sample average approximation method, a stochastic optimization technique.

sections.heading: 4. Price Prediction
sections.text: In this section, we describe how RoxyBot-06 builds its stochastic models of airfare, hotel and event prices. Each model is a discrete probability distribution represented by a series of "scenarios," each of which is a vector of "future" prices - prices at which goods can be bought and sold after the current phase. On flights, the price prediction model is not stochastical: the future purchase price is simply RoxyBot-06 "s prediction of the expected minimum price during the current phase. On hotels, future purchase prices are predicted by Monte Carlo simulations of simultaneous ascending auctions to approximate competitive equilibrium prices. There are no current purchase prices for hotels. For entertainment, RoxyBot-06 predicts future purchase and sale prices based on historical data. Details of these price prediction methods are at the center of this section.

sections.heading: 4.2.5 Summary
sections.text: The simulation methods discussed in this section - the ta-tonnement method and simultaneous ascending auctions - have only been used to predict hotel prices. (In our simulations, airfares are set to their expected minimums and maintenance prices to 80.) In principle, competitive equilibrium (CE) prices could serve as predictions in all TAC markets. However, CE prices are unlikely to be good predictions of airfares as airfares are determined exotically. In terms of maintenance prices, CE prices have strong predictive power; the inclusion of maintenance prices in the ta-tonne and SimAA calculations would have been expensive. (In our simulations according to Wellman et al., 2004, customer services are simply expanded to include fixed maintenance premiums that favor longer journeys.) Nevertheless, it may be interesting in future work to evaluate the success of these or related methods in predicting CDA clearing prices.

sections.text: In this section, we have described the price forecasting methods of RoxyBot-06. Key ideas that could be transferable, at least to other TAC agents, if not beyond the TAC, are as follows: 1. For hotels, RoxyBot uses a method inspired by Walverine: it approaches competitive equilibrium prices by simulating simultaneous ascending auctions instead of the usual ta-tonnement process.

sections.heading: 5. Optimization
sections.text: Next, we describe the optimization routine of RoxyBot-06. It is (i) stochastic, (ii) global, and (iii) dynamic, taking stochastic price forecasts as input, looking at its flight, hotel, and entertainment decisions in line, and at the same time justifying which bids should be made in both the current and future phases of the game.

sections.heading: 5.1 Abstract Auction Model
sections.text: Remember that our treatment of bidding is decision theory, not game theory. In particular, we focus on the problem of optimizing a single agent's own bidding behavior, provided that the strategies of the other agents are set. In accordance with our basic agent architecture, we also assume that the environment can be modeled based on the agent's predictions of market prices. We introduce the term pseudo-auction to refer to a market mechanism defined by these two assumptions - fixed behavior of other agents and market information encapsulated by prices. The optimization problem that RoxyBot solves is one of bidding in pseudo-auctions, not (true) auctions. In this section, we will formalize this abstract auction model and refer it to TAC auctions; in the next, we will define and propose heuristics to solve various pseudo-auction problems.

sections.heading: 5.4 Summary
sections.text: In this section, we have developed a series of bidding problems and heuristic solutions to these problems, which capture the essence of the bids in the one-time and continuous billing auctions that characterize the TACs. Most of our presentation was deliberately abstract to point out that our problems and their solutions are applicable well beyond the scope of the TACs: for example, to bids for interdependent goods in separate eBay auctions. Nevertheless, it remains to confirm our approach in other areas of application.

sections.text: We conclude this work with two experimental results, the first in a controlled test environment and the second with the results of the final round of the 2006 TAC Travel Competition. sections.heading: 6.3 Summary
sections.text: As already mentioned, TAC Travel's bidding process, which is considered an optimization problem, is an n-stage decision problem. We solve this n-stage decision problem as a sequence of 2-stage decision problems. The controlled experiments reported in this section show that our bidding strategy, SAA, is the best in our test series with only 2 stages in the environment for which it was designed. Results of the TAC competition show that this strategy is also effective in an n-stage environment.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text: Contributions to the design of commercial agents include the invention of trading strategies, along with models and algorithms for realizing their calculations and methods of measuring and evaluating the performance of commercial agents that are characterized by these strategies. Researchers are looking for both specific solutions to specific trade problems and general principles to guide the development of commercial agents across market scenarios. This paper claims to contribute to this research agenda. We described the design and implementation of RoxyBot-06, a capable commercial agent, as demonstrated by its performance in TAC-06. Although automated trading in electronic markets has not yet fully established itself, the trend is well advanced. TAC demonstrates the potential of autonomous bidders to make key trade decisions in the most effective way. Such agents have the potential to accelerate the automation of trade in a broader sense and thus shape the future of trade.

In spite of its effectiveness in the TAC-00 tournament, a weakness of the 2000 design was that RoxyBot could not explicitly reason about variance within prices. In the years since 2000, we recast the key challenges faced by TAC agents as several different stochastic bidding problems (see, for example, the paper by Greenwald & Boyan, 2004), whose solutions exploit price predictions in the form of distributions. In spite of our perseverance, RoxyBot fared unimpressively in tournament conditions year after year, until 2006. Half a decade in the laboratory spent searching for bidding heuristics that can exploit stochastic information at reasonable computational expense finally bore fruit, as RoxyBot emerged victorious in TAC-06. In a nutshell, the secret of RoxyBot-06’s success is: (hotel) price prediction by simulating simultaneous ascending auctions, and optimization based on the sample average approximation method. metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we describe our autonomous bidding agent, RoxyBot, who emerged victorious in the travel division of the 2006 Trading Agent Competition in a photo finish. At a high level, the design of many successful trading agents can be summarized as follows: (i) price prediction: build a model of market prices; and (ii) optimization: solve for an approximately optimal set of bids, given this model. To predict, RoxyBot builds a stochastic model of market prices by simulating simultaneous ascending auctions. To optimize, RoxyBot relies on the sample average approximation method, a stochastic optimization technique.
